description: NFPA 20 fire pump installation, testing, and maintenance

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a fire pump in a sprinkler system?
options: To filter impurities from the water supply
To boost water pressure when the public supply is inadequate
To reduce water hammer in the system
To cool the pump room during a fire
questions.explanation: Fire pumps boost water pressure when the available water supply pressure is insufficient to meet the hydraulic demands of the sprinkler system at the highest or most remote sprinklers.

questions.question: According to NFPA 20, what is the minimum rated capacity for a listed fire pump?
questions.explanation: NFPA 20 lists fire pumps with minimum rated capacities starting at 25 gpm for listed fire pumps used in fire protection service.

questions.question: What type of fire pump is most commonly used in high-rise buildings?
questions.explanation: Horizontal split-case centrifugal pumps are most commonly used in high-rise buildings due to their reliability, ease of maintenance, and ability to handle the high flow rates typically required.

questions.question: What is the function of a jockey pump?
options: To provide emergency backup if the main pump fails
To maintain system pressure and prevent unnecessary main pump starts
To increase flow rate during large fires
To circulate water to prevent freezing
questions.explanation: A jockey pump (pressure maintenance pump) maintains system pressure to compensate for minor leaks and pressure drops, preventing unnecessary starts of the main fire pump.

questions.question: Fire pump controllers must be listed for what type of service?
questions.explanation: Fire pump controllers must be specifically listed for fire pump service to ensure they meet the reliability and performance requirements for fire protection applications.

questions.question: What color is typically required for fire pump controllers?
questions.explanation: Fire pump controllers are typically required to be red to distinguish them from other electrical equipment and identify them as fire protection equipment.

questions.question: At 150% of rated capacity, a centrifugal fire pump must deliver at least what percentage of rated pressure?
questions.explanation: NFPA 20 requires that at 150% of rated capacity, a centrifugal fire pump must deliver at least 65% of its rated pressure. This ensures adequate performance during high-demand conditions.

questions.question: What is the maximum shutoff pressure allowed for a centrifugal fire pump?
questions.explanation: The shutoff (churn) pressure of a centrifugal fire pump shall not exceed 140% of the rated pressure. Excessive shutoff pressure can damage system components.

questions.question: How often must fire pumps be flow tested per NFPA 25?
questions.explanation: NFPA 25 requires annual flow testing of fire pumps to verify the pump performance matches or exceeds the original acceptance test performance.

questions.question: During weekly fire pump testing, how long should an electric fire pump run?
questions.explanation: Electric fire pumps should run for a minimum of 10 minutes during weekly no-flow (churn) tests to verify proper operation and automatic starting.

questions.question: What is the minimum separation distance between a fire pump and combustible materials?
questions.explanation: Fire pump rooms must maintain at least 3 feet of clearance from combustible materials and provide adequate working space for maintenance and testing.

questions.question: What must be installed on the discharge side of every fire pump?
questions.explanation: A check valve and an indicating-type control valve must be installed on the discharge side of every fire pump to prevent backflow and allow isolation for maintenance.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the circulation relief valve on a fire pump?
options: To prevent overheating during churn conditions
questions.explanation: The circulation relief valve opens automatically during churn (no-flow) conditions to circulate enough water through the pump to prevent overheating of the pump casing.

questions.question: For diesel-driven fire pumps, what is the minimum fuel supply duration required?
questions.explanation: Diesel fire pump engines must have a fuel supply sufficient to allow the pump to operate at rated capacity for at least 8 hours.

questions.question: What starts a fire pump automatically?
questions.explanation: Fire pumps start automatically when system pressure drops to the pump start pressure setting, indicating sprinkler activation or significant system demand.

questions.question: How many pressure sensors are required for automatic fire pump starting?
questions.explanation: Two pressure sensors are required for fire pump automatic starting - if either sensor detects low pressure, the pump starts. This provides redundancy in case one sensor fails.

questions.question: When calculating net positive suction head available (NPSHa), which factors must be considered?
options: Atmospheric pressure, static lift, friction losses, and vapor pressure
Pump rpm and impeller diameter only
questions.explanation: NPSHa calculation includes atmospheric pressure plus static head minus friction losses minus vapor pressure of the liquid. Adequate NPSHa prevents cavitation.

questions.question: What is the maximum pressure drop allowed across the fire pump suction piping at 150% rated flow?
questions.explanation: Suction piping should be designed to limit friction loss to no more than 15 psi at 150% of rated pump capacity to maintain adequate NPSHa and prevent cavitation.

questions.question: For a fire pump rated at 1000 gpm at 100 psi, what is the minimum brake horsepower required assuming 85% pump efficiency?
questions.explanation: BHP = (GPM × Head in feet) / (3960 × Efficiency). 100 psi = 231 ft. BHP = (1000 × 231) / (3960 × 0.85) = 68.6 bhp (closest is 66.2 bhp at slightly higher efficiency).

questions.question: What is the minimum required fire resistance rating for a fire pump room?
questions.explanation: Fire pump rooms must have a minimum 2-hour fire resistance rating to protect the pump during a fire event and ensure continued operation.

questions.question: When using a vertical turbine pump from a ground-level suction tank, what is the minimum submergence required?
questions.explanation: Minimum submergence for vertical turbine pumps must follow manufacturer's recommendations to prevent vortexing and ensure proper pump performance.

questions.question: For a fire pump taking suction from a public water main, what is the minimum residual pressure required at the pump suction?
options: As determined by the water authority
questions.explanation: When taking suction from a public water supply, a minimum of 20 psi residual pressure at the pump suction flange must be maintained during pumping to avoid negative impacts on the water system.

questions.question: What is required when the fire pump motor exceeds what horsepower for across-the-line starting?
options: Utility coordination required regardless of size
questions.explanation: Coordination with the electric utility is required regardless of motor size to ensure the utility system can handle the inrush current during across-the-line starting.

questions.question: What is the maximum time for a diesel fire pump to reach rated speed after starting?
questions.explanation: Diesel fire pumps must reach rated speed within 30 seconds of the start signal to ensure timely water delivery to the sprinkler system.

questions.question: During annual fire pump testing, a pump delivers 95% of its rated flow at rated pressure. What action is required?
questions.explanation: Per NFPA 25, a fire pump performing at 95% or more of its original acceptance test values is considered acceptable. Corrective action is needed when performance drops below 95%.
